description: From Middle English rumblen, romblen, rummelyn, frequentative form of romen (“to roar”), equivalent to rome +‎ -le. Cognate with Dutch rommelen (“to rumble”), Low German rummeln (“to rumble”), German rumpeln (“to be noisy”), Danish rumle (“to rumble”), all of imitative origin.

entries.meaning: A low, heavy, continuous sound, such as that of thunder or a hungry stomach.
examples: The rumble from passing trucks made it hard to sleep at night.

entries.meaning: A rotating cask or box in which small articles are smoothed or polished by friction against each other.
(dated) A seat for servants, behind the body of a carriage.
examples: Kit, well wrapped,  […]  was in the rumble behind.

verbs.description: rumble (third-person singular simple present rumbles, present participle rumbling, simple past and past participle rumbled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a low, heavy, continuous sound.
examples: If I don't eat, my stomach will rumble.
I could hear the thunder rumbling in the distance.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To discover deceitful or underhanded behaviour.
examples: The police is going to rumble your hideout.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move while making a rumbling noise.
examples: The truck rumbled over the rough road.

entries.meaning: (video games, intransitive, of a game controller) to provide haptic feedback by vibrating.
(transitive) To cause to pass through a rumble, or polishing machine.
